plugins.name: Auto Layout Remover
plugins.description:
Auto Layout Remover helps you quickly clean up messy Figma files and make them easier to edit or prototype.


When to use it:

  1. You want to redesign freely. If your design is full of auto layouts and deeply nested frames, and you just want to move things around without dealing with layout constraints ‚Äî this plugin flattens everything so you can edit with ease.
  2. You‚Äôre building an interactive prototype. Auto layouts often create layers and nesting that block or overlap each other. This plugin helps you clean the structure fast ‚Äî so you can bring the right blocks to the top and avoid layout issues.


What it does:

  1. Turns off all auto layouts, keeping objects in place
  2. Ungroups frames and groups without visible styles (no fill, no stroke, or hidden)
  3. Deletes hidden layers and empty frames
  4. Leaves instances and styled frames untouched
  5. Makes your file flat, clean, and easy to work with
plugins.tagline: Remove all auto layouts, empty frames, and groups in one click.

plugins.name: Fieldnotes
plugins.description:
Fieldnotes transforms in-person workshop sticky notes into digital boards.


Simply take photos of your sticky notes using your phone (you just have to scan a QR code to sync) or upload images directly to the plugin. Your physical sticky notes are instantly recreated in your board, preserving the texts, colors, position, and all your ideas :)


Fieldnotes combines several AI recognition technologies to boost accuracy and to detect even messy handwriting across multiple languages.

Pro users gain access to powerful AI-enhanced features including text improvement, grammar correction, and automatic workshop summaries.


Transform raw workshop notes into polished, actionable content and generate comprehensive takeaways to share with stakeholders, a dream follow-up!


If you want to learn more about the plugin or simply because you are passionate about Product or collaboration, feel free to reach out
plugins.tagline: Fieldnotes transforms pictures of sticky notes into stickies ‚Äî ready to share, without the hassle

plugins.name: Easy Task Prioritiser
plugins.description:
Easy Task Prioritiser‚Ä®Quickly organize and rank your tasks using two proven prioritization frameworks ‚Äî right inside Figma.


‚ú® How It Works

üî¢ Stack Ranking

Go to the Stack tab.

Enter your list of tasks.

Click Start Comparison to begin.

You‚Äôll be shown two tasks at a time ‚Äî choose which is more important.

Repeat until all tasks are compared and ranked.

In the end:

You'll get a clear, ranked list of tasks

You can Copy to Clipboard or Push to Canvas to bring the list into your Figma file


üß† MoSCoW Prioritization

Switch to the MoSCoW tab.

Add your tasks.

For each task, select whether it‚Äôs a Must, Should, Could, or Won‚Äôt.

Once done, use Push to Canvas to generate a structured visual layout by category.

In the end:

You can Copy to Clipboard or Push to Canvas to see tasks grouped by priority


This plugin is perfect for product teams, designers, and facilitators who want to make prioritization decisions quickly ‚Äî and stay focused on what matters most.
plugins.tagline: Turn messy task lists into clear priorities.

Subsections

plugins.name: Move Outside
plugins.description:
A plugin designed to move any elements outside of their current frames and place them at the top of the hierarchy while retaining their original position relative to the entire page. The plugin offers two modes:


  1. Default - Moves selected single or multiple elements to the top of the page‚Äôs layer hierarchy.
  2. Locked Target - Moves selected single or multiple elements into another specified layer. The Locked Target mode supports moving into frames, frames with autolayout, and sections. If the Locked Target is an autolayout frame, users can choose whether the moved frames should retain their original page position using absolute positioning or adapt to the autolayout.


This plugin stands out from others with similar functionality by offering a full interface that enables continuous management of complex layer structures.
plugins.tagline: A plugin used to move elements to the top of the layer hierarchy or to other frames/sections.

plugins.name: Lint copy
plugins.description:
Lint copy helps UX writers and content designers automatically enforce style rules with a custom word list.


Enforce things like plain language (e.g. detect "utilize" and suggest replacing it with "use"), the company's voice and tone (e.g. detect "we are" and suggest using the contraction), and even product terminology.


Create a custom word list in JSON and host it in a public GitHub repository to experience the plugin's full power.


The plugin also enforces sentence case and strings starting with a capital, neither of which is customizable.


For full details, read the documentation.
plugins.tagline: Check text layers against a word list to enforce style, voice, and terminology.

plugins.name: Figma Recall
plugins.description:
This plugin lets you save, manage, and switch between different versions (iterations) of your Figma frames.


Save an Iteration: Select a frame and click the Save button to save its current state.


Save with a Note: Hold Ctrl/Cmd and click the Save button to add a text description to your saved iteration.


Recall All Iterations: Select a frame and click the Recall button to view all its saved versions side-by-side.


Update Iterations: Make changes in the recalled container frame for any version and click Save to update with your changes in the stored master versions.


Navigate Versions: Use the < and > arrow buttons to cycle through saved iterations directly on your canvas.


Delete All Iterations: Select a frame and click the Delete button (trash icon) to remove all its saved versions.


Rename Iterations: Right-click the Save button to rename the selected frame and its entire group of saved iterations.
plugins.tagline: Version History but for Each Frame

plugins.name: Select by Style
plugins.description:
Select by Style makes it easy to find and select all elements on your page that share the same text or colour styling.


Perfect for designers who need to quickly audit styles, make bulk changes, or ensure consistency across their designs. Save time by selecting multiple elements at once instead of hunting them down individually.


What it does:

The plugin automatically scans your current page and organises all text styles and colour styles into easy-to-browse tables. Simply click on any style to instantly select all elements using that style across your page.


How to use it:

  1. Open the plugin to see all styles detected on your current page
  2. Browse the Text tab to see text styles with font details, sizes, and weights
  3. Browse the Colour tab to see colour styles with hex codes and opacity
  4. Use the search bar to quickly find specific styles by name, font, or colour
  5. Click any style row to select all elements using that style
  6. Use the Refresh button when you add new content to the page


Key features:

  1. Instant selection: Click once to select all elements with the same style
  2. Smart organisation: Separate tabs for text and colour styles with detailed information
  3. Search & filter: Quickly find styles by typing in the search box
  4. Library detection: See which styles are local vs. from external libraries
  5. Auto-refresh: Detects when you switch pages or add significant new content
  6. Live updates: Automatically updates when you change styles on selected elements


How are we doing? We're always working to make this plugin better and would genuinely appreciate hearing about your experience - and suggestions for enhancement.
plugins.tagline: Quickly select all elements using the same style

plugins.name: another-data-populator
plugins.description:
Another Data Populator


A Figma plugin that populates your designs with JSON.


How it works


1. Create a Layer Group that contains at least one Text Layer. In the Text Layer content, use placeholders for you data fields in double curly brackets ‚Äì such as {{firstname}} or {{lastname}}. The plugin will replace all these placeholders with respective data. _Please note that if your Text Layer is called {{name}} (in the Layer List), the content of the Layer will always be overwritten with the data contained in {{name}}. So if you use multiple {{placeholders}} in a Text Layer, you should rename your Layer to something without curly brackets._


2. In the same Layer Group, create a Shape Layer (this is your image placeholder). Give the Shape Layer a placeholder name in double curly brackets ‚Äì such as {{image}}. The plugin will replace this placeholder with respective image data (PNG or JPG).


3. For JSON arrays, create a Layer Group with a placeholder name like {{items}}. That group must contain one child Group Layer with the name {{template}}. This is the group that will be cloned and populated with the JSON array data. This works recursively with nested data. The array placeholder can have an optional limit filter {{items | limit 5}}, which will limit the number of {{template}} clones.


Available Commands


Populate with Dummy JSON

The plugin includes presets from https://dummyjson.com/ including:


- Products

- Carts

- Recipes

- Users

- Posts

- Comments

- Todos

- Quotes


Populate with Imported JSON

You can also upload any JSON file from your machine.


Filters

By appending your {{placeholder}} with one of the following available filters, separated by a |, you can use certain operations on your populated strings.


1. Maximum characters

You can set the maximum number of characters of your {{placeholder}} by appending it with | max n, 'n' representing the desired number of characters.


{{name | max 3}}


2. Date

Display {{placeholder}} in MM/DD/YYYY format.


{{dateTimeString | date}}


Conditional Actions

A Conditional Action performs a certain action on a Layer Group or Component based on data and a conditional expression. The Conditional Action is controlled by the name of the Layer Group (or Component).


1. #show[condition]

shows layer if true and hides otherwise


2. #hide[condition]

hides layer if true and shows otherwise


2. #duplicate[condition]

duplicate layer n times


3. #variant[condition, component property]

set component property based on condition


Examples

#show[{{firstname}}.length > 3]

shows layer if {{firstname}} has more than 3 characters and hides otherwise


#show[{{firstname}} == "Peter"]

shows layer if {{firstname}} is 'Peter' and hides otherwise


#duplicate[{{rating}}]

duplicates the layer by the value of {{rating}}


#variant[{{completed}}, Value Type = Checked]

sets the component property "Value Type" to "Checked" if {{completed}} is true


You can combine several conditions:


#show[{{firstname}}.includes('e') || {{firstname}}.length > 3]

shows layer if {{firstname}} includes 'e' or has more than 3 characters, hides otherwise


Or several Conditional Actions:


#variant[{{completed}}, Value Type = Checked] #variant[{{completed}}, State = Completed]

sets the component properties "Value Type" to "Checked" and "State" to "Completed" if {{completed}} is true


Pure JavaScript syntax is being used for Conditional Actions, so you can basically use anything available in JavaScript.
plugins.tagline: Populate your designs with JSON

plugins.name: Change Variable Descriptions
plugins.description:
Tired of manually updating each Figma variable‚Äôs description? This plugin streamlines the process by allowing you to update all variable descriptions simultaneously using a CSV file. This means you can ensure your design system stays consistent and well-documented‚Äîwithout the hassle of repetitive edits.


How It Works:


‚Ä¢Prepare Your CSV: Create a CSV file with the format: token_name,description. Ensure each variable name in your CSV matches exactly (1:1) with the ones in Figma; the plugin is sensitive to misspellings and will skip any mismatches.

‚Ä¢Select Variable Collection(s): Choose one or multiple variable collections based on your CSV file. (Recommendation: create a separate CSV for each collection.)

‚Ä¢Preview Changes: Review the highlighted changes in a table before applying them, ensuring accuracy and control over the update process.

‚Ä¢Apply Updates: With just a few clicks, update all selected variable descriptions in your Figma design system.


Streamline your design documentation, avoid manual errors, and keep your design tokens up-to-date effortlessly!
plugins.tagline: Simplify workflow: Update variable descriptions in one click

plugins.name: SPLOC - Selected the parent of component layer
plugins.description:
A plugin for Figma that automatically selects the parent component when any child within the component or its instance is selected.


Main features:

  1. Automatic detection and selection of the parent component
  2. Automatic collapse of the selected component
  3. On/Off switch to enable/disable functionality
  4. Memories the last selection to prevent cyclic selections


How to use:

  1. Install the plugin
  2. Launch the plugin (it is active by default)
  3. Select any element within the component or its instance
  4. The plugin will automatically:
  5. Finds the parent component
  6. Select it
  7. Flattens the structure of the component


Interface:

  1. Compact window with ON/OFF switch
  2. The switch allows you to temporarily disable plugin functionality


Technical features:

  1. Works with components (COMPONENT) and their instances (INSTANCE)
  2. Prevents cyclic selections
  3. Optimized for working with large files
  4. Minimal impact on Figma performance


Application:

Ideal for working with large component systems where switching between children and parent components is often required.

plugins.name: Sizr
plugins.description: Sizr is a Figma plugin designed to streamline the process of resizing elements within a frame. By leveraging the column grid layout of the parent frame, the plugin ensures precise alignment and proportional scaling of selected elements. Whether you‚Äôre working with rectangles, text layers, groups, or components, Column Sizr dynamically calculates the appropriate dimensions based on the grid‚Äôs column count, margins, and gutter size. Simply select your elements, define the desired number of columns, and let the plugin handle the rest. Ideal for designers aiming for consistency and accuracy in grid-based designs.
plugins.tagline: Resize elements dynamically based on the column grid of their parent frame.

111068.name: Sizr
111068.description: Sizr is a Figma plugin designed to streamline the process of resizing elements within a frame. By leveraging the column grid layout of the parent frame, the plugin ensures precise alignment and proportional scaling of selected elements. Whether you‚Äôre working with rectangles, text layers, groups, or components, Column Sizr dynamically calculates the appropriate dimensions based on the grid‚Äôs column count, margins, and gutter size. Simply select your elements, define the desired number of columns, and let the plugin handle the rest. Ideal for designers aiming for consistency and accuracy in grid-based designs.
111068.release_notes:
Support for Components
Added:
- The plugin now supports resizing elements based on the grid of a parent `COMPONENT` in addition to a `FRAME`.
- Automatically detects whether the parent is a `FRAME` or `COMPONENT` with a valid grid layout.
- Displays appropriate notifications if resizing is restricted (e.g., when dealing with a master component).

Fixed:
- Improved error handling and user feedback for unsupported parent types or missing grid layouts.

How to Use:
1. Select an element within a `FRAME` or `COMPONENT` with a grid.
2. Trigger the plugin to resize compatible elements based on the grid layout.
111068.tagline: Resize elements dynamically based on the column grid of their parent frame.

plugins.name: Fijira
plugins.description:
Streamline your workflow and eliminate the gap between design and project management with Fijira. This powerful plugin seamlessly connects your Figma designs directly to your Jira tickets, ensuring that your development team always has access to the latest frames, feedback, and design specifications.


Stop wasting time manually exporting assets and pasting links. With Fijira, you can create detailed Jira comments, update ticket statuses, and link specific Figma frames directly from within your design file.


Key Features:


One-Click Jira Comments: Create rich, formatted comments in Jira tickets directly from Figma.

Automatic Frame Linking: Automatically attach a link to your selected Figma frame. If no frame is selected, you have the option to paste a link manually.

Status Updates: View available transitions and update the status of your Jira tickets without leaving Figma.

Simple Markdown Editor: Format your comments with bold, italics, lists, and links to keep your communication clear and organized.

Secure & Private: Your Jira credentials are saved securely in your local Figma storage and are never exposed. All communication happens through a secure, private proxy server.

Easy Setup: A simple, one-time setup for your Jira domain, email, and API token gets you started in minutes.

How to Use:


Run the Plugin: Open Fijira from the plugins menu.

Enter Your Settings: In the settings view, enter your Jira domain (e.g., your-company.atlassian.net), your Jira account email, and a valid Jira API token.

Select a Frame (Optional): Select a single frame in your Figma file that you want to link.

Fill in Commit Details: In the commit view, enter a commit title, a detailed description (using the markdown editor!), and the target Jira issue key (e.g., PROJ-123).

Update Status (Optional): Choose a new status for your Jira ticket from the dropdown menu.

Commit! Click "Commit & Update Jira". Fijira will post your comment, link, and status change to the specified Jira ticket and create a new version in your Figma file history.

Say goodbye to context switching and hello to a more efficient workflow with Fijira!
plugins.tagline: Sync your Figma designs with Jira issue, seamlessly.

plugins.name: FigJsonizer
plugins.description:
This plugin lets you select any frame or component in Figma and instantly convert it into a clean, structured JSON object. It's perfect for devs building UI components, syncing data with code, or generating design specs.


No network needed, no fluff‚Äîjust fast, reliable JSON export from your Figma canvas. Copy the data to clipboard and use it wherever your workflow takes you: React, Angular, JSON-based APIs‚Äîyou name it.


Ideal for design-to-dev handoff, prototyping, and frontend engineering.
plugins.tagline: Generate and copy clean JSON from selected Figma frames.
